name: Cross-site scripting (DOM-based)

description:
The application may be vulnerable to DOM-based cross-site scripting. Data is read from input.value and passed to element.innerHTML.

This vulnerability has been assigned a 'Tentative' confidence rating. Burp Scanner has identified that a vulnerability is present, but the severity is highly dependent on whether exploitation requires the victim to manually interact with the vulnerable page in a dangerous way. To determine the severity, you need to perform additional manual testing.

You can replicate the technique used by Burp Scanner and confirm that self-exploitation is possible by injecting a suitable payload via the input field. However, if you can find a way to deliver the payload without requiring the victim to effectively exploit themselves, the severity may be significantly higher. For example, you may be able to inject the payload via a query parameter, meaning the exploit is triggered as soon as the victim visits a malicious URL.

If neither of these approaches work, the identified behavior is likely to be unexploitable.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the User-Agent HTTP header is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload ekny2<script>alert(1)</script>cywck was submitted in the User-Agent HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the page request parameter is copied into the value of an HTML tag attribute which is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload e7v71"><script>alert(1)</script>g4daw was submitted in the page parameter. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the URL path filename is copied into the application's response.

name: File path traversal
description:
The page parameter is vulnerable to path traversal attacks, enabling read access to arbitrary files on the server.

The payload ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd was submitted in the page parameter. The requested file was returned in the application's response.

name: File path manipulation
description:
The page parameter appears to be vulnerable to file path manipulation attacks.

The payload .htaccess was submitted in the page parameter. The file .htaccess was returned.

name: Client-side HTTP parameter pollution (reflected)
description:
The value of the page request parameter is copied into the response within the query string of a URL.

The payload ptq&cvs=1 was submitted in the page parameter. This input was echoed unmodified within the "href" attribute of an "a" tag.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary query string parameters into URLs in the application's response.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the URL path folder 1 is copied into the application's response.

name: Path-relative style sheet import
description:
The application may be vulnerable to path-relative style sheet import (PRSSI) attacks. The first four conditions for an exploitable vulnerability are present (see issue background):
  1. The original response contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 1).
  2. When superfluous path-like data is placed into the URL following the original filename (see request 2), the application's response still contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 2).
  3. Response 2 can be made to render in a browser's quirks mode. The page does not contain a doctype directive, and so it will always be rendered in quirks mode. Further, the response does not prevent itself from being framed, so an attacker can frame the response within a page that they control, to force it to be rendered in quirks mode. (Note that this technique is IE-specific and due to P3P restrictions might sometimes limit the impact of a successful attack.)
  4. When the path-relative style sheet import in response 2 is requested (see request 3) the application returns something other than the CSS response that was supposed to be imported (see response 3).
It was not verified whether condition 5 holds (see issue background), and you should manually investigate whether it is possible to manipulate some text within response 3, to enable full exploitation of this issue.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the User-Agent HTTP header is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload qzyww<script>alert(1)</script>s3rhk was submitted in the User-Agent HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the username request parameter is copied into the application's response.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the Referer HTTP header is copied into the application's response.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the username request parameter is copied into a JavaScript string which is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload 41080";alert(1)//219 was submitted in the username parameter. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.
remediation: Echoing user-controllable data within a script context is inherently dangerous and can make XSS attacks difficult to prevent. If at all possible, the application should avoid echoing user data within this context.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the Referer HTTP header is copied into the value of an HTML tag attribute which is an event handler and is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload 71107';alert(1)//999 was submitted in the Referer HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

Note that the input is echoed into an existing event handler within the response. JavaScript injected into this context will only execute when the relevant event occurs. This may require some action by the victim user, and may hinder exploitation. It may be possible to manually fine tune an attack to increase the likelihood that the event occurs.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.
remediation: Echoing user-controllable data within an event handler is inherently dangerous and can make XSS attacks difficult to prevent. The defense of HTML-encoding user-controllable data is not effective in this context, because browsers will HTML-decode the event handler string before executing it as script.  If at all possible, the application should avoid echoing user data within this context.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the URL path filename is copied into the application's response.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the showhints cookie is copied into the application's response.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the showhints cookie is copied into a JavaScript string which is encapsulated in single quotation marks. The payload [0x00]74541';alert(1)//734 was submitted in the showhints cookie. This input was echoed as 74541';alert(1)//734 in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

The application attempts to block certain characters that are often used in XSS attacks but this can be circumvented by submitting a NULL byte anywhere before the characters that are being blocked.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a cookie, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. Typically, you will need to find a means of setting an arbitrary cookie value in the victim's browser in order to exploit the vulnerability. Applications often contain "cookie-forcing" conditions which make this possible, and such a condition in any related domain or subdomain can potentially be used for this purpose. Nonetheless, this limitation somewhat mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.
remediation: Echoing user-controllable data within a script context is inherently dangerous and can make XSS attacks difficult to prevent. If at all possible, the application should avoid echoing user data within this context. NULL byte bypasses typically arise when the application is being defended by a web application firewall (WAF) that is written in native code, where strings are terminated by a NULL byte. You should fix the actual vulnerability within the application code, and if appropriate ask your WAF vendor to provide a fix for the NULL byte bypass.

name: Path-relative style sheet import
description:
The application may be vulnerable to path-relative style sheet import (PRSSI) attacks. The first four conditions for an exploitable vulnerability are present (see issue background):
  1. The original response contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 1).
  2. When superfluous path-like data is placed into the URL following the original filename (see request 2), the application's response still contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 2).
  3. Response 2 can be made to render in a browser's quirks mode. The page does not contain a doctype directive, and so it will always be rendered in quirks mode. Further, the response does not prevent itself from being framed, so an attacker can frame the response within a page that they control, to force it to be rendered in quirks mode. (Note that this technique is IE-specific and due to P3P restrictions might sometimes limit the impact of a successful attack.)
  4. When the path-relative style sheet import in response 2 is requested (see request 3) the application returns something other than the CSS response that was supposed to be imported (see response 3).
It was not verified whether condition 5 holds (see issue background), and you should manually investigate whether it is possible to manipulate some text within response 3, to enable full exploitation of this issue.

The application may be vulnerable to path-relative style sheet import (PRSSI) attacks. The first four conditions for an exploitable vulnerability are present (see issue background):
  1. The original response contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 1).
  2. When superfluous path-like data is placed into the URL following the original filename (see request 2), the application's response still contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 2).
  3. Response 2 can be made to render in a browser's quirks mode. The page does not contain a doctype directive, and so it will always be rendered in quirks mode. name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the PHPSESSID cookie is copied into the application's response.

name: SQL injection
description:
The name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. A single quote was submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter, and a database error message was returned. Two single quotes were then submitted and the error message disappeared. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

Additionally, the payload 80220470' or '5865'='5865 was submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter, and a database error message was returned. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

The database appears to be MySQL.
remediation: The application should handle errors gracefully and prevent SQL error messages from being returned in responses.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

name: SQL injection
description:
The User-Agent HTTP header appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. A single quote was submitted in the User-Agent HTTP header, and a database error message was returned. Two single quotes were then submitted and the error message disappeared. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

Additionally, the payload 12267792' or 5293=5293-- was submitted in the User-Agent HTTP header, and a database error message was returned. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

The database appears to be MySQL.
remediation: The application should handle errors gracefully and prevent SQL error messages from being returned in responses.

name: SQL injection
description:
The Referer HTTP header appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. A single quote was submitted in the Referer HTTP header, and a database error message was returned. Two single quotes were then submitted and the error message disappeared. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

Additionally, the payload 47587734' or 7850=7850-- was submitted in the Referer HTTP header, and a database error message was returned. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

The database appears to be MySQL.
remediation: The application should handle errors gracefully and prevent SQL error messages from being returned in responses.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the Referer HTTP header is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload lchyi<script>alert(1)</script>trcq3 was submitted in the Referer HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

name: Path-relative style sheet import
description:
The application may be vulnerable to path-relative style sheet import (PRSSI) attacks. The response contains a path-relative style sheet import, and so condition 1 for an exploitable vulnerability is present (see issue background). The response can also be made to render in a browser's quirks mode. Although the page contains a modern doctype directive, the response does not prevent itself from being framed. An attacker can frame the response within a page that they control, to force it to be rendered in quirks mode. (Note that this technique is IE-specific and due to P3P restrictions might sometimes limit the impact of a successful attack.) This means that condition 3 for an exploitable vulnerability is probably present if condition 2 is present.

Burp was not able to confirm that the other conditions hold, and you should manually investigate this issue to confirm whether they do hold.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. name: Open redirection (reflected)
description:
The value of the Referer HTTP header is used to perform a redirect initiated from JavaScript. The payload http://a3lvlqkwjlq/a?http://10.1.3.2/mutillidae/ was submitted in the Referer HTTP header. This caused a redirection to the following URL:
  • http://a3lvlqkwjlq/a?http://10.1.3.2/mutillidae/


Because the data used in the redirection is submitted within a header, the application's behavior is unlikely to be directly useful in lending credibility to a phishing attack. This limitation considerably mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

name: Path-relative style sheet import
description:
The application may be vulnerable to path-relative style sheet import (PRSSI) attacks. The first four conditions for an exploitable vulnerability are present (see issue background):
  1. The original response contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 1).
  2. When superfluous path-like data is placed into the URL following the original filename (see request 2), the application's response still contains a path-relative style sheet import (see response 2).
  3. Response 2 can be made to render in a browser's quirks mode. Although the page contains a modern doctype directive, the response does not prevent itself from being framed. An attacker can frame the response within a page that they control, to force it to be rendered in quirks mode. (Note that this technique is IE-specific and due to P3P restrictions might sometimes limit the impact of a successful attack.)
  4. When the path-relative style sheet import in response 2 is requested (see request 3) the application returns something other than the CSS response that was supposed to be imported (see response 3).
It was not verified whether condition 5 holds (see issue background), and you should manually investigate whether it is possible to manipulate some text within response 3, to enable full exploitation of this issue.

name: Request URL override
description:
The application appears to support the use of a custom HTTP header to override the Host header.

Burp added the following headers to the request:

X-Forwarded-Host: 2wzbmgc4xf0wvenrusdbi9d7aygr8fzhnaoyel49t.oastify.com
X-Host: 2wzbmgc4xf0wvenrusdbi9d7aygr8fzhnaoyel49t.oastify.com
X-Forwarded-Server: 2wzbmgc4xf0wvenrusdbi9d7aygr8fzhnaoyel49t.oastify.com

A value from these headers was reflected in the response, showing that a header was processed.

evidence.poc: PoC

description: The application may be vulnerable to DOM-based client-side JSON injection. Data is read from postMessage and passed to JSON.parse.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the rev request parameter is copied into the value of an HTML tag attribute which is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload }}ta8wv"><script>alert(1)</script>mb9fm was submitted in the rev parameter. This input was echoed as ta8wv"><script>alert(1)</script>mb9fm in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the rev request parameter is copied into the HTML document as text between TITLE tags. The payload }}goep1</title><script>alert(1)</script>l7lgn was submitted in the rev parameter. This input was echoed as goep1</title><script>alert(1)</script>l7lgn in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

name: OS command injection
description:
The rev parameter appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands and retrieve the output in the application's responses. Additionally it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability.

The payload |echo anjamn2kqg 9pre97aa5h||a #' |echo anjamn2kqg 9pre97aa5h||a #|" |echo anjamn2kqg 9pre97aa5h||a # was submitted in the rev parameter. The application's response appears to contain the output from the injected command, indicating that the command was executed.

Additionally, the payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the rev parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the page request parameter is copied into the value of an HTML tag attribute which is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload ly3kk"><script>alert(1)</script>bvdw8l8t57n was submitted in the page parameter. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

The original request used the POST method, however it was possible to convert the request to use the GET method, to enable easier demonstration and delivery of the attack.

name: OS command injection
description:
The search parameter appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands. The command output does not appear to be returned in the application's responses, however it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability.

The payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the search parameter. The application took 20506 milliseconds to respond to the request, compared with 618 milliseconds for the original request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

name: SQL injection
description:
The blog_entry parameter appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. A single quote was submitted in the blog_entry parameter, and a database error message was returned. Two single quotes were then submitted and the error message disappeared. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

Additionally, the payload 23572350' or 4285=4285-- was submitted in the blog_entry parameter, and a database error message was returned. You should review the contents of the error message, and the application's handling of other input, to confirm whether a vulnerability is present.

The database appears to be MySQL.
remediation: The application should handle errors gracefully and prevent SQL error messages from being returned in responses.

name: Suspicious input transformation (reflected)
description:
The application appears to unescape backslash escape sequences when processing the value of the target_host request parameter, and echo the result in the response.

The payload qeqvt57n75\\loajyjsajo was submitted in the target_host parameter. This payload contains the '\\' sequence, which commonly represents an escaped backslash. The input was copied into the application's response as qeqvt57n75\loajyjsajo indicating that the application unescaped the '\\' sequence as '\'.

This behavior indicates that the application might be evaluating the input within some interpreted context, which might give rise to code injection or other issues. It might also be possible to cause the application to differently interpret characters from the start of any data that is concatenated onto the input, by finishing the payload with a single backslash character.

name: OS command injection
description:
The target_host parameter appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands and retrieve the output in the application's responses. Additionally it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability.

The payload |echo i41o59zjtm ryhtrukmer||a #' |echo i41o59zjtm ryhtrukmer||a #|" |echo i41o59zjtm ryhtrukmer||a # was submitted in the target_host parameter. The application's response appears to contain the output from the injected command, indicating that the command was executed.

Additionally, the payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the target_host parameter. The application took 20296 milliseconds to respond to the request, compared with 273 milliseconds for the original request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

name: OS command injection
description:
The URL path filename appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use the pipe character (|) to inject arbitrary OS commands and retrieve the output in the application's responses.

The payload |echo 5bn8aiz088 ehllcohrpp||a #' |echo 5bn8aiz088 ehllcohrpp||a #|" |echo 5bn8aiz088 ehllcohrpp||a # was submitted in the URL path filename. The application's response appears to contain the output from the injected command, indicating that the command was executed.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the User-Agent HTTP header is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload qzyww<script>alert(1)</script>s3rhk was submitted in the User-Agent HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the User-Agent HTTP header is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload wpodh<script>alert(1)</script>t33m9o5a1if was submitted in the User-Agent HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

The original request used the POST method, however it was possible to convert the request to use the GET method, to enable easier demonstration and delivery of the attack.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the Referer HTTP header is copied into the value of an HTML tag attribute which is an event handler and is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload 71107';alert(1)//999 was submitted in the Referer HTTP header. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

Note that the input is echoed into an existing event handler within the response. JavaScript injected into this context will only execute when the relevant event occurs. This may require some action by the victim user, and may hinder exploitation. It may be possible to manually fine tune an attack to increase the likelihood that the event occurs.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a request header, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. In the past, methods have existed of using client-side technologies such as Flash to cause another user to make a request containing an arbitrary HTTP header. If you can use such a technique, you can probably leverage it to exploit the XSS flaw. This limitation partially mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.
remediation: Echoing user-controllable data within an event handler is inherently dangerous and can make XSS attacks difficult to prevent. The defense of HTML-encoding user-controllable data is not effective in this context, because browsers will HTML-decode the event handler string before executing it as script.  If at all possible, the application should avoid echoing user data within this context.

The original request used the POST method, however it was possible to convert the request to use the GET method, to enable easier demonstration and delivery of the attack.

The defense of HTML-encoding user-controllable data is not effective in this context, because browsers will HTML-decode the event handler string before executing it as script.  If at all possible, the application should avoid echoing user data within this context.

name: Cross-site request forgery
description: The request appears to be vulnerable to cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks against unauthenticated functionality. This is unlikely to constitute a security vulnerability in its own right, however it may facilitate exploitation of other vulnerabilities affecting application users.

name: Cross-site request forgery
description: The request appears to be vulnerable to cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks against unauthenticated functionality. This is unlikely to constitute a security vulnerability in its own right, however it may facilitate exploitation of other vulnerabilities affecting application users.

name: Cross-site request forgery
description:
The request appears to be vulnerable to cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks against unauthenticated functionality. This is unlikely to constitute a security vulnerability in its own right, however it may facilitate exploitation of other vulnerabilities affecting application users.

The original request contains parameters that look like they may be anti-CSRF tokens. However the request is successful if these parameters are removed.

The original request contains parameters that look like they may be anti-CSRF tokens. However, the values of these parameters do not change if the submitting form is reloaded without supplying any cookies. Hence, the parameters are probably not being used as anti-CSRF tokens.

name: OS command injection

dns_event.description:
The Collaborator server received a DNS lookup of type CNAME for the domain name 536EtjJ74i7Z2hUU1VKepCkaH1nUFidH1Dp5Cv0k.OastiFY.COM.

The lookup was received from IP address 172.253.2.211:54516 at 2025-Sep-04 15:09:19.944 UTC.

description:
The target_host parameter appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands and retrieve the output in the application's responses. Additionally it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability. It is also possible to cause the application to interact with an external domain, to verify that a command was executed.

The payload |nslookup -q=cname 536etjj74i7z2huu1vkepckah1nufidh1dp5cv0k.oastify.com.& was submitted in the target_host parameter. The application performed a DNS lookup for the specified domain name.

Additionally, the payload |echo i41o59zjtm ryhtrukmer||a #' |echo i41o59zjtm ryhtrukmer||a #|" |echo i41o59zjtm ryhtrukmer||a # was submitted in the target_host parameter. The application's response appears to contain the output from the injected command, indicating that the command was executed.

Additionally, the payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the target_host parameter. The application took 20296 milliseconds to respond to the request, compared with 273 milliseconds for the original request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

name: External service interaction (DNS)

dns_event.description:
The Collaborator server received a DNS lookup of type A for the domain name a2DJsoIc3n641Mtz00JJOhJFg6mZenCm0eo6bwzL.oaStify.COm.

The lookup was received from IP address 172.253.12.212:56491 at 2025-Sep-04 15:09:27.000 UTC.

description:
It is possible to induce the application to perform server-side DNS lookups of arbitrary domain names.

The payload a2djsoic3n641mtz00jjohjfg6mzencm0eo6bwzl.oastify.com was submitted in the target_host parameter.

The application performed a DNS lookup of the specified domain.

name: Out-of-band resource load (HTTP)

The Collaborator server received an HTTP request.

The request was received from IP address 154.144.237.193:38531 at 2025-Sep-04 15:14:42.527 UTC.

description:
It is possible to induce the application to retrieve the contents of an arbitrary external URL and return those contents in its own response.

The payload http://211brgh42f5w0esrzsibn9i7fylrdfbkzdn5avyk.oastify.com/hacking/auditool.txt was submitted in the textfile parameter.

The application performed an HTTP request to the specified domain. The response from that request was then included in the application's own response.

description:
The page parameter is vulnerable to path traversal attacks, enabling read access to arbitrary files on the server.

The payload ../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../../etc/passwd was submitted in the page parameter. The requested file was returned in the application's response.

name: File path manipulation
description:
The page parameter appears to be vulnerable to file path manipulation attacks.

The payload .htaccess was submitted in the page parameter. The file .htaccess was returned.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the username request parameter is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload hrzui<script>alert(1)</script>k0oeg was submitted in the username parameter. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

name: Client-side HTTP parameter pollution (reflected)
description:
The value of the page request parameter is copied into the response within the query string of a URL.

The payload nrq&uhi=1 was submitted in the page parameter. This input was echoed unmodified within the "href" attribute of an "a" tag.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary query string parameters into URLs in the application's response.

name: Input returned in response (reflected)
description: The value of the phpfile request parameter is copied into the application's response.

name: File path manipulation
description:
The topic parameter appears to be vulnerable to file path manipulation attacks.

The payload ./ was submitted in the topic parameter. This returned the same content as the base request. The payload .../ was then submitted, and this returned a different response. This indicates that the application may be vulnerable to file path manipulation.

name: Cross-site scripting (reflected)
description:
The value of the phpfile request parameter is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload i68o4<script>alert(1)</script>wwyrl was submitted in the phpfile parameter. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to inject arbitrary JavaScript into the application's response.

name: Link manipulation (reflected)
description:
The value of the topic request parameter is copied into the response within the path of a URL.

The payload 4st50ypeus was submitted in the topic parameter. This input was echoed unmodified within the "href" attribute of a "base" tag.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to modify the URL to reference an arbitrary path.

name: Form action hijacking (reflected)
description:
The value of the topic request parameter is copied into the response within the path of a form action URL.

The payload 4st50ypeus was submitted in the topic parameter. This input was echoed unmodified within a form action URL.

This proof-of-concept attack demonstrates that it is possible to modify the form action to reference an arbitrary path.
